messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 55 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Towards Optimal Effective Resistance Estimation

Paper Abstract: Abstract We provide new algorithms and conditional hardness for the problem of estimating effective resistances in n𝑛n-node, m𝑚m-edge, undirected, expander graphs. We provide an O~​(m​ϵ−1)~𝑂𝑚superscriptitalic-ϵ1\widetilde{O}(m\epsilon^{-1})-time algorithm that produces with high probability, an O~​(n​ϵ−1)~𝑂𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ1\widetilde{O}(n\epsilon^{-1})-bit sketch from which the effective resistance between any pair of nodes can be estimated, to (1±ϵ)plus-or-minus1italic-ϵ(1\pm\epsilon)-multiplicative accuracy, in O~​(1)~𝑂1\widetilde{O}(1)-time. Consequently, we obtain an O~​(m​ϵ−1)~𝑂𝑚superscriptitalic-ϵ1\widetilde{O}(m\epsilon^{-1})-time algorithm for estimating the effective resistance of all edges in such graphs, improving (for sparse graphs) on the previous fastest runtimes of O~​(m​ϵ−3/2)~𝑂𝑚superscriptitalic-ϵ32\widetilde{O}(m\epsilon^{-3/2}) [1] and O~​(n2​ϵ−1)~𝑂superscript𝑛2superscriptitalic-ϵ1\widetilde{O}(n^{2}\epsilon^{-1}) [2] for general graphs and O~​(m+n​ϵ−2)~𝑂𝑚𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ2\widetilde{O}(m+n\epsilon^{-2}) for expanders [3]. We complement this result by showing a conditional lower bound that a broad set of algorithms for computing such estimates of the effective resistances between all pairs of nodes require Ω~​(n2​ϵ−1/2)~Ωsuperscript𝑛2superscriptitalic-ϵ12\widetilde{\Omega}(n^{2}\epsilon^{-1/2})-time, improving upon the previous best such lower bound of Ω~​(n2​ϵ−1/13)~Ωsuperscript𝑛2superscriptitalic-ϵ113\widetilde{\Omega}(n^{2}\epsilon^{-1/13}) [4]. Further, we leverage the tools underlying these results to obtain improved algorithms and conditional hardness for more general problems of sketching the pseudoinverse of positive semidefinite matrices and estimating functions of their eigenvalues.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 55 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 55"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Graph sparsification, spectral sketches, and faster resistance computation, via short cycle decompositions",
        "Efficient O~​(n/ϵ)~𝑂𝑛italic-ϵ\\widetilde{O}(n/\\epsilon) spectral sketches for the laplacian and its pseudoinverse",
        "A new approach to estimating effective resistances and counting spanning trees in expander graphs",
        "Spectrum approximation beyond fast matrix multiplication: Algorithms and hardness",
        "Effective resistance is more than distance: Laplacians, simplices and the schur complement",
        "Kirchhoff index as a measure of edge centrality in weighted networks: Nearly linear time algorithms",
        "Resistance distance",
        "Graph sparsification by effective resistances",
        "Constructing linear-sized spectral sparsification in almost-linear time",
        "Fully dynamic spectral vertex sparsifiers and applications",
        "Fast graph attention networks using effective resistance based graph sparsification",
        "Skeleton-based action recognition using sparse spatio-temporal gcn with edge effective resistance",
        "Efficient sampling for gaussian graphical models via spectral sparsification",
        "Improved large-scale graph learning through ridge spectral sparsification",
        "Effective resistance against pandemics: Mobility network sparsification for high-fidelity epidemic simulations",
        "Electrical flows, laplacian systems, and faster approximation of maximum flow in undirected graphs",
        "Navigating central path with electrical flows: from flows to matchings, and back",
        "Computing maximum flow with augmenting electrical flows",
        "Faster maxflow via improved dynamic spectral vertex sparsifiers",
        "Minimum cost flows, mdps, and ℓ1subscriptℓ1\\ell_{1}-regression in nearly linear time for dense instances",
        "Path finding methods for linear programming: Solving linear programs in o (vrank) iterations and faster algorithms for maximum flow",
        "Sampling random spanning trees faster than matrix multiplication",
        "An almost-linear time algorithm for uniform random spanning tree generation",
        "Fast generation of random spanning trees and the effective resistance metric",
        "Graph clustering using effective resistance",
        "Effective-resistance preserving spectral reduction of graphs",
        "On over-squashing in message passing neural networks: The impact of width, depth, and topology",
        "Oversquashing in gnns through the lens of information contraction and graph expansion",
        "Understanding oversquashing in gnns through the lens of effective resistance",
        "Affinity-aware graph networks",
        "Dynamic effective resistances and approximate schur complement on separable graphs",
        "Towards resistance sparsifiers",
        "Subcubic equivalences between path, matrix, and triangle problems",
        "Faster matrix multiplication via asymmetric hashing",
        "On sketching quadratic forms",
        "Spectral subspace sparsification",
        "Fully dynamic electrical flows: Sparse maxflow faster than goldberg–rao",
        "On the complexity of partial derivatives",
        "Note on a lower bound on the linear complexity of the fast fourier transform",
        "Lower bounds for matrix product",
        "Algorithms and lower bounds for replacement paths under multiple edge failures",
        "Subcubic equivalences between graph centrality measures and complementary problems",
        "Extensions of lipschitz mappings into hilbert space",
        "Database-friendly random projections",
        "Finding frequent items in data streams",
        "Countsketches, feature hashing and the median of three",
        "Approximate gaussian elimination for laplacians: Fast, sparse, and simple",
        "A simple, combinatorial algorithm for solving sdd systems in nearly-linear time",
        "A local clustering algorithm for massive graphs and its application to nearly-linear time graph partitioning",
        "Ultrasparse ultrasparsifiers and faster laplacian system solvers",
        "A Lower Bound for the Smallest Eigenvalue of the Laplacian",
        "Exploiting numerical sparsity for efficient learning : Faster eigenvector computation and regression",
        "Global convergence of non-convex gradient descent for computing matrix squareroot",
        "Cauchy’s interlace theorem for eigenvalues of hermitian matrices",
        "User-friendly tail bounds for sums of random matrices"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 55 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Towards Optimal Effective Resistance Estimation, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
